subcommands.name: ipfs block
subcommands.description: 'ipfs block' is a plumbing command used to manipulate raw IPFS blocks. Reads from stdin or writes to stdout. A block is identified by a Multihash passed with a valid CID.
subcommands.usage: ipfs block - Interact with raw IPFS blocks.

subcommands.name: ipfs block get
subcommands.description: 'ipfs block get' is a plumbing command for retrieving raw IPFS blocks. It takes a <cid>, and outputs the block to stdout.
subcommands.usage: ipfs block get <cid> - Get a raw IPFS block.

subcommands.name: ipfs block put
subcommands.description: 'ipfs block put' is a plumbing command for storing raw IPFS blocks. It reads data from stdin, and outputs the block's CID to stdout. Unless cid-codec is specified, this command returns raw (0x55) CIDv1 CIDs. Passing alternative --cid-codec does not modify imported data, nor run any validation. It is provided solely for convenience for users who create blocks in userland. NOTE: Do not use --format for any new code. It got superseded by --cid-codec and left only for backward compatibility when a legacy CIDv0 is required (--format=v0).
subcommands.usage: ipfs block put <data>... - Store input as an IPFS block.

options.description: Disable block size check and allow creation of blocks bigger than 1MiB. WARNING: such blocks won't be transferable over the standard bitswap.
Multicodec to use in returned CID.
Use legacy format for returned CID (DEPRECATED).
Multihash hash length.
Multihash hash function.
Pin added blocks recursively.

subcommands.description: 'ipfs block rm' is a plumbing command for removing raw ipfs blocks. It takes a list of CIDs to remove from the local datastore.
subcommands.name: ipfs block rm

options.description: Ignore nonexistent blocks.
Write minimal output.

subcommands.description:
'ipfs block stat' is a plumbing command for retrieving information on raw IPFS blocks. It outputs the following to stdout:

  Key  - the CID of the block
  Size - the size of the block in bytes
subcommands.name: ipfs block stat
subcommands.usage: ipfs block stat <cid> - Print information of a raw IPFS block.

subcommands.name: ipfs init
subcommands.description: Initializes ipfs configuration files and generates a new keypair. If you are going to run IPFS in server environment, you may want to initialize it using 'server' profile. For the list of available profiles see 'ipfs config profile --help'. ipfs uses a repository in the local file system. By default, the repo is located at ~/.ipfs. To change the repo location, set the $IPFS_PATH environment variable: export IPFS_PATH=/path/to/ipfsrepo
subcommands.usage: ipfs init [<default-config>] - Initializes ipfs config file.

options.description: Cryptographic algorithm to use for key generation.
Number of bits to use in the generated RSA private key.
Don't add and pin help files to the local storage.
Apply profile settings to config. Multiple profiles can be separated by ','.

subcommands.description: IPNS is a PKI namespace, where names are the hashes of public keys, and the private key enables publishing new (signed) values. In both publish and resolve, the default name used is the node's own PeerID, which is the hash of its public key.
subcommands.name: ipfs name

subcommands.description: Prints values inside of IPNS Record protobuf and its DAG-CBOR Data field. The input can be a file or STDIN, the output can be JSON. Values in PublicKey, SignatureV1 and SignatureV2 fields are raw bytes encoded in Multibase. The Data field is DAG-CBOR represented as DAG-JSON. Passing --verify will verify signature against provided public key.
subcommands.name: ipfs name inspect
subcommands.usage: ipfs name inspect <record> - Inspects an IPNS Record

options.description: Include a full hex dump of the raw Protobuf record.
CID of the public IPNS key to validate against.

subcommands.description: Publish IPNS names.
subcommands.usage: ipfs name publish <ipfs-path> - Publish IPNS names.

options.description: When offline, save the IPNS record to the local datastore without broadcasting to the network instead of simply failing.
Encoding used for keys: Can either be a multibase encoded CID or a base58btc encoded multihash. Takes {b58mh|base36|k|base32|b...}.
Name of the key to be used or a valid PeerID, as listed by 'ipfs key list -l'.
Time duration that the record will be valid for. This accepts durations such as "300s", "1.5h" or "2h45m". Valid time units are "ns", "us" (or "Âµs"), "ms", "s", "m", "h".
Write only final hash.
Check if the given path can be resolved before publishing.
Time duration this record should be cached for. Uses the same syntax as the lifetime option. (caution: experimental).
Produce a backward-compatible IPNS Record by including fields for both V1 and V2 signatures.

subcommands.name: ipfs name resolve
subcommands.description: IPNS is a PKI namespace, where names are the hashes of public keys, and the private key enables publishing new (signed) values. In both publish and resolve, the default name used is the node's own PeerID, which is the hash of its public key. You can use the 'ipfs key' commands to list and generate more names and their respective keys.

options.description: Write just hashes of objects.
Enable streaming of pins as they are discovered.
The type of pinned keys to list. Can be "direct", "indirect", "recursive", or "all".

An optional name for the pin.

Allow removal of multiple pins matching the query without additional confirmation.

ipfs pin remote service ls
subcommands.description: List remote pinning services.

options.description: Try to fetch and display current pin count on remote service (queued/pinning/pinned/failed).

subcommands.description: A command-line tool for interacting with IPFS.

subcommands.description: Remove credentials for access to a remote pinning service.

subcommands.name: ipfs pin remote service rm pin rm
subcommands.description: Remove credentials for access to a remote pinning service.
subcommands.usage: ipfs pin remote service rm <service> - Remove remote pinning service.

subcommands.description: Removes the pin from the given object allowing it to be garbage collected if needed. (By default, recursively. Use -r=false for direct pins.) A pin may not be removed because the specified object is not pinned or pinned indirectly. To determine if the object is pinned indirectly, use the command: ipfs pin ls -t indirect <cid>
subcommands.name: ipfs pin rm
subcommands.usage: ipfs pin rm <ipfs-path>... - Remove object from pin-list.

options.description: Recursively unpin the object linked to by the specified object(s).

subcommands.name: ipfs pin update
subcommands.description: Efficiently pins a new object based on differences from an existing one and, by default, removes the old pin. This command is useful when the new pin contains many similarities or is a derivative of an existing one, particularly for large objects. This allows a more efficient DAG-traversal which fully skips already-pinned branches from the old object. As a requirement, the old object needs to be an existing recursive pin.
subcommands.usage: ipfs pin update <from-path> <to-path> - Update a recursive pin.

options.description: Remove the old pin.

subcommands.name: ipfs pin verify
subcommands.description: Verify that recursive pins are complete.

options.description: Write just hashes of broken pins.
Also write the hashes of non-broken pins.

subcommands.name: ipfs ping
subcommands.description: 'ipfs ping' is a tool to test sending data to other nodes. It finds nodes via the routing system, sends pings, waits for pongs, and prints out round-trip latency information.
subcommands.usage: ipfs ping <peer ID>... - Send echo request packets to IPFS hosts.

options.description: Number of ping messages to send.

subcommands.name: ipfs pubsub
subcommands.description: ipfs pubsub allows you to publish messages to a given topic, and also to subscribe to new messages on a given topic. DEPRECATED FEATURE (see https://github.com/ipfs/kubo/issues/9717) It is not intended in its current state to be used in a production environment. To use, the daemon must be run with '--enable-pubsub-experiment'.
subcommands.usage: ipfs pubsub - An experimental publish-subscribe system on ipfs.

subcommands.description: ipfs pubsub ls lists out the names of topics you are currently subscribed to.
subcommands.name: ipfs pubsub ls

options.description: Inspect the format by encoding/decoding multibase strings in the userland.

subcommands.usage: ipfs pubsub ls - List subscribed topics by name.

subcommands.description: ipfs pubsub peers with no arguments lists out the pubsub peers you are currently connected to. If given a topic, it will list connected peers who are subscribed to the named topic. DEPRECATED FEATURE (see https://github.com/ipfs/kubo/issues/9717)
subcommands.name: ipfs pubsub peers

subcommands.description: ipfs pubsub pub publishes a message to a specified topic. It reads binary data from stdin or a file.
subcommands.name: ipfs pubsub pub
subcommands.usage: ipfs pubsub pub <topic> <data> - Publish data to a given pubsub topic.

options.description: Enable the pubsub experiment, required for publishing messages.

subcommands.description: DEPRECATED, command will be removed in the future. ipfs pubsub sub subscribes to messages on a given topic.
subcommands.name: ipfs pubsub sub

options.description: To use, the daemon must be run with '--enable-pubsub-experiment'.
You can inspect the format by passing --enc=json.

subcommands.usage: ipfs routing findprovs <key>... - Find peers that can provide a specific value, given a key.

options.description: The number of providers to find.
Print extra information.

subcommands.description: Outputs the best value for the given key. There may be several different values for a given key stored in the routing system; in this context 'best' means the record that is most desirable. There is no one metric for 'best': it depends entirely on the key type. For IPNS, 'best' is the record that is both valid and has the highest sequence number (freshest). Different key types can specify other 'best' rules.
subcommands.name: ipfs routing get
ipfs routing provide

subcommands.description: Verify objects in the filestore. If one or more <obj> is specified only verify those specific objects, otherwise verify all objects. The output is: <status> <hash> <size> <path> <offset> Where <status> is one of: ok: the block can be reconstructed changed: the contents of the backing file have changed no-file: the backing file could not be found error: there was some other problem reading the file missing: <obj> could not be found in the filestore ERROR: internal error, most likely due to a corrupt database For ERROR entries the error will also be printed to stderr.
subcommands.name: ipfs filestore verify

options.description: Verify the objects based on the order of the backing file.

subcommands.description: There are a number of mutable name protocols that can link among themselves and into IPNS. subcommands.name: ipfs swarm connect
subcommands.description: 'ipfs swarm connect' attempts to ensure a connection to a given peer. Multiaddresses given are advisory, for example the node may already be aware of other addresses for a given peer or may already have an established connection to the peer. The address format is a libp2p multiaddr.
subcommands.usage: ipfs swarm connect <address>... - Open connection to a given peer.

subcommands.name: ipfs swarm disconnect
subcommands.description: 'ipfs swarm disconnect' closes a connection to a peer address. The address format is an IPFS multiaddr. The disconnect is not permanent; if ipfs needs to talk to that address later, it will reconnect.
subcommands.usage: ipfs swarm disconnect <address>... - Close connection to a given address.

subcommands.name: ipfs swarm filters
subcommands.description: 'ipfs swarm filters' will list out currently applied filters. Its subcommands can be used to add or remove said filters. Filters are specified using the multiaddr-filter format.

subcommands.description: 'ipfs swarm filters add' will add an address filter to the daemons swarm.

subcommands.description: DEPRECATED, command will be removed in the future
subcommands.name: ipfs dht get

subcommands.description: Outputs the best value for the given key. There may be several different values for a given key stored in the routing system; in this context 'best' means the record that is most desirable. There is no one metric for 'best': it depends entirely on the key type. For IPNS, 'best' is the record that is both valid and has the highest sequence number (freshest). Different key types can specify other 'best' rules.
subcommands.name: ipfs dht get dht
subcommands.usage: ipfs dht get <key>... - Given a key, query the routing system for its best value.

subcommands.name: ipfs dht provide
subcommands.description: Announce to the network that you are providing given values.
subcommands.usage: ipfs dht provide <key>... - Announce to the network that you are providing given values.

options.description: Recursively provide entire graph.
Print extra information.

subcommands.description: Given a key of the form /foo/bar and a valid value for that key, this will write that value to the routing system with that key. Keys have two parts: a keytype (foo) and the key name (bar). IPNS uses the /ipns keytype, and expects the key name to be a Peer ID. IPNS entries are specifically formatted (protocol buffer). You may only use keytypes that are supported in your ipfs binary: currently this is only /ipns. Unless you have a relatively deep understanding of the go-ipfs routing internals, you likely want to be using 'ipfs name publish' instead of this. The value must be a valid value for the given key type. For example, if the key is /ipns/QmFoo, the value must be IPNS record (protobuf) signed with the key identified by QmFoo.

options.description: When offline, save the IPNS record to the the local datastore without broadcasting to the network instead of simply failing.

options.description: Maximum number of bytes to read.
Byte offset to begin reading from.
Stream progress data.

subcommands.description:
Files is an API for manipulating IPFS objects as if they were a Unix filesystem.

The files facility interacts with MFS (Mutable File System). MFS acts as a single, dynamic filesystem mount. MFS has a root CID that is transparently updated when a change happens (and can be checked with "ipfs files stat /").

All files and folders within MFS are respected and will not be deleted during garbage collections. However, a DAG may be referenced in MFS without being fully available locally (MFS content is lazy loaded when accessed). MFS is independent from the list of pinned items ("ipfs pin ls"). Calls to "ipfs pin add" and "ipfs pin rm" will add and remove pins independently of MFS. If MFS content that was additionally pinned is removed by calling "ipfs files rm", it will still remain pinned.

Content added with "ipfs add" (which by default also becomes pinned), is not added to MFS. Any content can be lazily referenced from MFS with the command "ipfs files cp /ipfs/<cid> /some/path/" (see ipfs files cp --help).

NOTE:
Most of the subcommands of 'ipfs files' accept the '--flush' flag. It defaults to true. Use caution when setting this flag to false. It will improve performance for large numbers of file operations, but it does so at the cost of consistency guarantees. If the daemon is unexpectedly killed before running 'ipfs files flush' on the files in question, then data may be lost. This also applies to run 'ipfs repo gc' concurrently with '--flush=false' operations.
subcommands.name: ipfs files

options.description: Flush target and ancestors after write.

subcommands.name: ipfs files chcid
subcommands.description: Change the CID version or hash function of the root node of a given path.
subcommands.usage: ipfs files chcid [<path>] - Change the CID version or hash function of the root node of a given path.

options.description: Cid version to use. (experimental).
Hash function to use. Will set Cid version to 1 if used. (experimental).

subcommands.name: ipfs files cp
subcommands.description: Add references to IPFS files and directories in MFS (or copy within MFS).

options.description: Make parent directories as needed.

subcommands.name: ipfs files flush
subcommands.description: Flush a given path's data to disk.
List directories in the local mutable namespace (works on both IPFS and MFS paths).
subcommands.name: ipfs files ls

options.description: Use long listing format.
Do not sort; list entries in directory order.

subcommands.name: ipfs files mkdir
subcommands.description: Create the directory if it does not already exist.

options.description: Cid version to use. (experimental).
Hash function to use. Will set Cid version to 1 if used. (experimental).
No error if existing, make parent directories as needed.

subcommands.description: Move files around. Just like the traditional Unix mv.
subcommands.name: ipfs files mv
ipfs files read
subcommands.description: Read a specified number of bytes from a file at a given offset. By default, it will read the entire file similar to the Unix cat.
subcommands.usage: ipfs files read <path> - Read a file from MFS.

options.description: Byte offset to begin reading from.
Maximum number of bytes to read.

subcommands.description: Remove files or directories.
subcommands.name: ipfs files rm

options.description: Forcibly remove target at path; implies -r for directories.
Recursively remove directories.

subcommands.name: ipfs files stat
subcommands.description: Display file status.

options.description: Print statistics in given format. Allowed tokens: <hash> <size> <cumulsize> <type> <childs>. Conflicts with other format options.
Print only hash. Implies '--format=<hash>'. Conflicts with other format options.
Print only size. Implies '--format=<cumulsize>'. Conflicts with other format options.
Compute the amount of the dag that is local, and if possible the total size.

subcommands.description: A low-level MFS command that allows you to append data at the end of a file, or specify a beginning offset within a file to write to. The entire length of the input will be written. If the '--create' option is specified, the file will be created if it does not exist. Nonexistent intermediate directories will not be created unless the '--parents' option is specified. Newly created files will have the same CID version and hash function of the parent directory unless the '--cid-version' and '--hash' options are used. Newly created leaves will be in the legacy format (Protobuf) if the CID version is 0, or raw if the CID version is non-zero. Use of the '--raw-leaves' option will override this behavior. If the '--flush' option is set to false, changes will not be propagated to the merkledag root. This can make operations much faster when doing a large number of writes to a deeper directory structure.
subcommands.name: ipfs files write

options.description: Cid version to use. (experimental).
Create the file if it does not exist.
Hash function to use. Will set Cid version to 1 if used. (experimental).
Make parent directories as needed.
Use raw blocks for newly created leaf nodes. (experimental).
Byte offset to begin writing at.
Maximum number of bytes to read.
Truncate the file to size zero before writing.

subcommands.usage: ipfs files write <path> <data> - Append to (modify) a file in MFS.
